sen.j: 冥加（みょうが）とは、江戸時代に山野河海などを利用したり、営業などの免許の代償として江戸幕府や藩に対して支払った租税の1種。
sen.e: Myoga means a kind of tax in the Edo period that was paid to the Edo bakufu or domains in consideration of the use of mountains/fields/rivers/seas or the grant of business licence.

sen.j: 金銭で支払われることが多かったために、冥加金（みょうがきん）・冥加永（みょうがえい、「永」＝永楽通宝）とも呼ばれている。
sen.e: Since it was usually paid in cash, it was also called Myogakin/Myogaei (ei means Eiraku-tsuho (bronze coins)).

sen.j: 本来、「冥加」とは冥利と同義語で、神仏からの加護の意味である。
sen.e: Originally, a term Myoga was the synonym of myori, which means divine protection.

sen.j: 冥加の祈願あるいは冥加を受けたことに対する謝礼として寺院や神社に奉納された金銭や物資のことも「冥加」と称するようになった。
sen.e: Money and goods that were offered to temples/shrines as gratuity for the prayer of Myoga or receiving Myoga also came to be called "Myoga".

sen.j: 後に領主権力も自己を領民の庇護者としての恩恵（国恩）を強調した。
sen.e: Later, feudal lords claimed to be the protectors of the people of the domain and stressed the benefit of the existence of such protectors (kokuon (benefit given by the lord of domain)).

sen.j: これを口実に年貢を納めない商工業者に対して農民の年貢に相当する冥加を求めるようになった。
sen.e: On the pretext of the above, feudal lords imposed Myoga, which corresponded to nengu (land tax) imposed on farmers, on merchants and traders who were not required to pay nengu.

sen.e: Further, they imposed Myoga on people who gained profit from the business that required the license of the domain, such as mine workers, as well as people who gained profit from mountains/fields/rivers/seas that were under the rule of lords, such as whale fishermen.
